Description: A head broken from the hollow terracotta figure of a dog, wearing a large floral wreath, with another garland or perhaps a collar round its neck. From a multiple-piece mould; certainly two, perhaps more. Red-brown Nile silt, brown at the core, and containing some mica and white inclusions. Overall fired-on white slip. Some of the painted detail may also be of fired-on ceramic colours: red on the collar/garland and on the dog's muzzle; eyes and brows are black, as also are areas on the large wreath. The pink that also decorates this wreath is probably a post-firing paint.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Donated: Egypt Exploration Fund. Excavated at Oxyrhynchus. Roman, first to second century AD. Comparandum: Not unlike Matelly 2003: 609, no. 73, from Maximianon in the Wadi Hammamat, context between the time of Nero and Marcus Aurelius.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3767)
